actions.headline: Get in touch ASAP
actions.text: Taking the initiative to contact your landlord will help build trust and allow your landlord to make plans on their end.

actions.headline: Make yourself available
actions.text: Answer any calls, emails, or texts from your landlord as soon as you get them. Being responsive respects their time and lets them know you aren't going to disappear.

actions.headline: Offer another solution
actions.text: Suggesting a temporary, alternate solution such as a partial payment or a payment plan is a sign of good faith and lets your landlord know you eventually intend to pay.

actions.headline: Apologize, but no excuses
actions.text: It may help to explain your situation if it's an emergency, but only if it leads to finding a viable payment solution.

actions.headline: Call your utility provider
actions.text: Most utility companies have programs that can help people in need with their bills, including creating a payment plan.

actions.headline: Find government assistance
actions.text: Many state and local government agencies have alternative assistance programs for utilities. Find out more here:

actions.headline: Apply for LIHEAP
actions.text: Assistance is available through the federal Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program (each state has their own set of qualifications).

criteria: Residents with very young children, elderly, or disabled family members.
Homes with low-incomes and high regional costs.

actions.headline: Contact your local 2-1-1
actions.text: They can connect you with resources related to housing (availability varies by location).

actions.headline: Find a Catholic Charities agency
actions.text: They can help you with services related to housing (availability varies by location).

actions.headline: Apply for a Modest Needs grant
actions.text: These small, emergency grants are allocated to low-income workers. Find out more by visiting their website.

actions.headline: Talk to a counselor
actions.text: If you won't be able to pay your rent for a while, the best thing you can do right now is get personalized advice from a counselor.

link.text: FIND A HOUSING COUNSELOR NEAR YOU

actions.headline: Open a savings account
actions.text: Savings can give you a cushion for future crises. Having a goal and timeline in mind when you open your account can give you the motivation to get started.

actions.headline: Start with a dollar today
actions.text: Savings is a long-term game and by getting started with something small, as soon as possible, you can set yourself up for future success.

actions.headline: Set up an automatic withdrawal
actions.text: Automati withdrawl makes saving easier by not having to think about it. Decide on an amount that works for you, even if it's $10 a month.

actions.headline: Find a savings buddy
actions.text: Having a partner can help you stay on track. Use this person to help you stay motivated, when you're tempted, or if it feels really hard. We all need support once in a while.

actions.headline: Save the documents and seek help
actions.text: Save all documents and seek help immediately. Save all notics and communications from your landlord, any lawyers, or courts. Understand the eviction process, your rights, and your options by speaking with a Legal Aid attorney.

link.text: FIND LEGAL HELP NEAR YOU NOW

actions.headline: Apply for unemployment benefits
actions.text: It's important to file as soon as possible as application processing, approval and first payment can take a few weeks.

8.text: See if you qualify for any government benefits

actions.headline: Take the Benefits assessment
actions.text: Government benefits can assist with a variety of costs from food to health coverage. Even if you can't get help directly with your rent, you may find you qualify for something that frees up money to help put towards your rent.
